column14: The lar describes the history of the house and criticizes the miserly character of its previous (and current) owners
Euclio is worried that Staphyla is spying on him
Euclio is worried that Staphyla is spying on him
Euclio uses a slave-specific insult formula; on Staphyla's status — bookends://sonnysoftware.com/18380
Euclio mocks and threatens Staphyla based largely on her status; on Staphyla's status — bookends://sonnysoftware.com/18380
Staphyla thinks Euclio is going insane and comments on his increasingly irrational behavior — see hook://file/2BjKOPbfb?p=Vmltd2lraS9aZXR0ZWxfV2lraQ==&n=210817-1249-insanity_insults-a.wiki
Staphyla remarks on the lack of food and supplies in the house (mocking Euclio's worry about thieves)
Euclio casually insults Staphyla despite her sound concern
Eunomia casually comments that "no women in history are ever quiet"; appears to be a cliche insult
Eunomia casually comments that "one woman is worse than another"
Euclio interprets Megadorus' friendly greeting as a stratagem to rob him (because M is wealthy)
Euclio believes that Staphyla has found and "revealed" his hidden gold to Megadorus
Euclio interprets Megadorus' friendly greeting as a stratagem to rob him (because M is wealthy); compares him to a "hungry octopus" (!!!)
Megadorus admits that Euclio seems to have been insulted by him; but M also comments on Euclio's miserliness
Euclio believes that the wealthy Megadorus is mocking him by asking to marry Euclio's dowry-less daughter
Euclio believes that the wealthy Megadorus is mocking him by asking to marry Euclio's dowry-less daughter; uses and elaborate livestock metaphor (bulls vs donkeys) to illustrate
Megadorus admits that Euclio seems to have been insulted by him
Euclio suggests that (because he is rich) Megadorus will not live by the agreement they have concocted
